headline: Ohio Redistricting Commission prepares to meet in response to supreme court rejection
author: Andy Chow | Statehouse News Bureau
sentences:
< < Back to
COLUMBUS, Ohio (Statehouse News Bureau) — The Ohio Redistricting Commission is planning to convene for a rare weekend meeting to take the first steps in response to the supreme court’s latest ruling.
The process for the three previous maps included the Republican and Democratic legislative caucuses drafting their own maps then proposing them to the commission.
LaRose said it is not possible for state legislative races to appear on the May 3 primary ballot, barring further action from federal court.
Secretary of State Frank LaRose (R-Ohio) sent a letter to DeWine and lawmakers Thursday evening to lay out the state of the May 3 primary.
Mike DeWine (R-Ohio) says he wants the commission to ask the Republican and Democratic mapmakers to work together on the next proposal.
We need to follow what the court has said and we need to follow all the things the court has told us in three different opinions.
But we also have to be able to match that and to do what the constitution requires us to do,” says DeWine.
The third attempt at drawing House and Senate maps was invalidated by a 4-3 opinion from the court.
Justices said the commission must draft a plan that does not unduly favor one party over another.
Legislative leaders have been reviewing their options since the court announced its ruling.
“This is a specialized art, and trying to get this done in ten days is important.
